[[Biedermeier]] |client = [[Duke Wilhelm of Urach]] |current_tenants = Duke Wilhelm Albert von Urach |renovation_date = [[1980 in Germany|1980]], [[1998 in Germany|1998]]–[[2002 in Germany|2002]] |height = {{convert|817|m|ft|abbr=off}}|etymology = Lichtenstein {{lang-en|Bright, shiny stone}}{{cite web |url=http://woerterbuchnetz.de/DWB/?lemma=licht |title=Meaning "light" or "sheen", "shine" |work=Woerterbuchnezt |publisher=Trier Center for Digital Humanities |accessdate=12 November 2016}} |logo = Wappen des Herzogs von Urach.svg |logo_size = 160 |logo_alt = Arms of the Dukes of Urach |logo_caption = Arms of the Dukes of Urach |image_caption = Lichtenstein Castle, circa [[2010 in Germany|2010]] |map_size = |map_dot_label = Schloss Lichtenstein |classification = Fairy tale Castle }} '''Lichtenstein Castle''' ({{lang-de|Schloss Lichtenstein}}), also known as the "Fairy tale castle of [[Württemberg]],"{{cite web|url=http://www.schloss-lichtenstein.de/index.php/en/history-family/history|title=History and family|publisher=Schloss Lichtenstein|accessdate=25 June 2015}} is an 1840s [[Biedermeier]]-style [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]] [[castle]] built on a large rock situated in the [[Swabian Jura]] and overlooking the [[Echaz]] Valley near [[Lichtenstein, Baden-Württemberg|Honau]], [[Reutlingen (district)|Reutlingen]] in the [[Tübingen (region)|Tüblingen]] region of [[Baden-Württemberg]], [[Germany]]. Though a few structures have stood on this spot, the current edifice was built between 1840 and 1842.{{cite web|title=Travel to Lichtenstein Castle|url=http://www.hivino.travel/discover-germany/medieval-castles-and-fairy-tale-villages/lichtenstein-castle--fairy-tales-come-true/e380|website=hivino.travel|publisher=HiVino}} ==Geography== The castle is located on the [[Albtrauf]] of the Swabian Jura in the Reutlingen district at an altitude of {{convert|817|m|ft|abbr=off}} [[above sea level]]{{cite web|title=Walkabout|url=http://www.schloss-lichtenstein.de/en/walkabout|publisher=Schloss Lichtenstein}} and about {{convert|250|m|ft|abbr=off}} above the Echaz river, a small tributary of the [[Neckar|Neckar river]]. The ruins of Schloss Lichtenstein's [[medieval]] predecessor, [[Alt-Lichtenstein Castle|Burg Alt-Lichtenstein]] ({{lang-en|Old Lichtenstein castle}}), lie {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=off}} away.{{cite web|title=Ruine Alt-Lichtenstein|url=http://www.gemeinde-lichtenstein.de/,Lde/Startseite/Freizeit+_+Tourismus/Ruine+Alt_Lichtenstein.html|website=gemeinde-lichtenstein.de|publisher=Municipality of Lichtenstein}} ==History== ===Background=== [[File:Lichtenstein Forsthaus.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The [[Forsthaus]] of 1802 atop the cliff, c. early 19th Century]] Since around 1100, a castle belonging to a family of [[Ministerialis|Ministerials]] of the [[Counts of Alchalm]], and later [[List of rulers of Württemberg#Counts of Württemberg to 1495|Counts of Württemberg]], has been located on this part of the Albtrauf above the source of the river Echaz.{{cite web|url=http://www.landesarchiv-bw.de/web/51160|title=Geschichte des Schlosses Lichtenstein|publisher=Landesarchiv Baden-Württemberg}} The castle and its denizens, the Lords of Lichtenstein, were not friends of the [[Free Imperial City]] of Reutlingen and were thus under frequent attack. The old castle was destroyed twice, once during the Reichskrieg of 1311 and again by the citizens of Reutlingen sometime between 1377 and 1381. A new castle was built in 1390 some {{convert|500|m|ft}} from the ruins (now referred to as Burg Alt-Lichtenstein) on the site of the current structure, and was one of the most impressive fortifications of the [[Late Middle Ages]]. Despite such features as early [[casemate]]s that made it nearly unassailable, the castle ceased to be the ducal seat in 1567 and fell into disrepair. During the [[Thirty Years War]] (1618–1648), it was taken over by the Tyrolean line of the [[Hapsburgs]] following the death of the last Lichtensteiner in 1687 during the [[Great Turkish War]].{{cite web|title=Chronology|url=http://www.schloss-lichtenstein.de/en/history-family/chronology|publisher=Schloss Lichtenstein}} The [[coat of arms]] of their family, a pair of golden angel wings on a blue background, is still displayed in the [[Rittersaal]] ({{lang-en|Knight's hall}}) of the castle. In 1802, King [[Frederick I of Württemberg]] came into possession of the castle, dismantled it to its foundations and replaced it with a somewhat ungainly hunting lodge, or [[Forsthaus]]. ===Modern castle=== In the wake of 19th Century [[Romanticism]], medieval virtues like [[chivalry]] became increasingly popular among the elites. Parallel to this, medieval architecture, primarily Gothic style, returned to public attention in Germany with the unfinished [[Cologne Cathedral]],{{#tag:ref|As was typical with the construction of [[cathedrals]],{{cite web|title=Cathedral Building in the Middle Ages|url=https://www.durhamworldheritagesite.com/architecture/cathedral/construction|publisher=Durham World Heritage Site}} Cologne Cathedral took a very long time to build. In the instance of Cologne Cathedral, construction began in 1248 and finally was completed in [[1880 in Germany|1880]].{{Cite web|title=Cologne Cathedral - UNESCO World Heritage Centre|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/292|website=whc.unesco.org|access-date=2016-02-11|language=en|first=UNESCO World Heritage|last=Centre}}|group=Note}} leading to the rise of [[Gothic Revival architecture]].The importance of the Cologne completion project in German-speaking lands has been explored by Michael J. Lewis, ''"The Politics of the German Gothic Revival: August Reichensperger"''. Other notable examples of this romantic infatuation with medieval structures and architecture from the greater region of Europe are the [[Votive Church, Vienna|Votive Cathedral]] of Vienna and [[Neuschwanstein Castle]] in Bavaria. The propagation of this style and the turn back to supposedly ancient national traditions, went along with the spread of [[nationalism]] across Europe, creating a new cultural era in Europe. In 1826, German poet and patriot [[Wilhelm Hauff]] published his book ''[[Lichtenstein (novel)|Lichtenstein]]'', in which the castle, the book's namesake, played a major role.[http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/6726 ''Lichtenstein'' by Wilhelm Hauff] at [[Project Gutenberg]]DK Publishing, p. 301 Hauff's novel was inspired by the [[Historical_fiction#19th_century|historical romances]] of [[Walter Scott]], some of which Hauff reviewed and wrote a parody about.[https://books.google.de/books?id=KoNlCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA260&lpg=PA260&dq=hauff+%C3%BCbersetzungsfabriken&source=bl&ots=ZnfqKJ9qz3&sig=VXpLEv4s0__H9X2Fsa8a0xozLuc&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwih8YCW6YvQAhUI4SYKHZaCBGsQ6AEIMzAD#v=onepage&q=hauff%20%C3%BCbersetzungsfabriken&f=false Stefan Knödler: "Heute geholt und morgen zurükgegeben" in: Archiv für Geschichte des Buchwesens, vol. 70, 2015, p. 260] King Frederick's cousin, Duke [[Duke Wilhelm of Urach|Wilhelm von Urach]], a German [[wikt:Patriot|patriot]], who was very interested in medieval history, art, and architecture, was so inspired by the book that he purchased the estate — at that time merely another crumbling ruin in the Swabian Jura — from the King in 1837, after negotiations for the purchase with the resident [[Oberförster]] Philipp Freiherr von Hügel and his successor [[Friedrich von Mandelsloh]].[https://www2.landesarchiv-bw.de/ofs21/olf/struktur.php?bestand=19957&sprungId=2693381&letztesLimit=suchen Negogiations for the purchase of the Forsthaus of 1802] inventory GU 20: Lichtenstein Castle: construction, use and management, 1. Background to the Castle building: purchase negotiations. [[File:Abbruch des Forsthauses auf dem Lichtenstein.jpg|thumb|left|Demolition of the Forsthaus, 1839]] Desiring an accurate emulation of a medieval castle to live in and house his substantial collection of medieval arts, arms, and armour, Duke Wilhelm recruited master architect and restorationist [[Carl Alexander Heideloff]] after turning down designs by Württemberg [[court painter]] [[Franz Seraph Stirnbrand]] and [[Christian Wilhelm von Faber du Faur]] - designs that differed substantially from today's structure. Construction of the historic gothic revival Neues Schloss Lichtenstein ({{lang-en|New Lichtenstein castle}}) began in 1840 and was managed by [[Johann Georg Rupp]]. The new structure, its design heavily influenced by Count Wilhelm, reused the ancient foundations of the castle of 1390, and stood up to three stories tall, with a curtain wall and courtyard to complete the castle complex. A [[barbican]] and a sprawling [[outer bailey]], complete with corner [[bastion]]s and [[turret]]s, was constructed in 1857. Following this, the castle was then decorated within and without by [[Nuremberg]] painter and architect [[Georg Eberlein]],Hartig, pp.98–106 and two altar panels by an Austrian known as the "[[Master of Schloss Lichtenstein]]."{{cite web|title=Master of Schloss Lichtenstein|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100446371|publisher=Oxford Index|encyclopedia=The Grove Encyclopedia of Northern Renaissance Art}} The castle was completed in 1842, and the King was present for its inauguration ceremony.{{cite web|title=Lichtenstein Castle|url=https://www.triposo.com/poi/W__31481768|publisher=Triposo}} With the castle complete, it became the official residence of the Dukes of Urach in 1869. After the [[German revolutions of 1848–49|Revolution of 1848]], then-Count Wilhelm became the [[Duke of Urach|First Duke of Urach]]. A passionate [[artillery]] officer, he desired to improve the defenses of his castle and so began to build pre-[[outwork]] [[caponier]]s in the style of the imperial [[Fortress of Ulm]] (though not on a scale as grand) and a [[trench]] along the fortress to deter attack. Later he had cannons placed in the bastions on the walls.Ottersbach, pp. 100–120 From [[1898 in Germany|1898]] to [[1901 in Germany|1901]] the two buildings left of the main gate, the "Fürstenbau" ({{lang-de|Baronial building}}) and the old forester's house, were constructed and expanded respectively. A motion to build a cableway up to the castle in 1911 was rejected because it was believed it would ruin the beauty of the castle. ===Restoration=== [[File:Lichtenstein - Lichtenstein Castle - inside 2012 (aka).jpg|thumb|Outer bailey structure]] The castle was damaged during [[World War II]]{{how|date=November 2016}}, but efforts to restore the castle began in the immediate aftermath of the Second World War. Once again, and thanks to local non-profit organizations like the [[Wüstenrot Foundation]]{{cite web|title=Sponsors + friends|url=http://www.schloss-lichtenstein.de/en/sponsors-friends|publisher=Schloss Lichtenstein}} and ''Community Fund for the Preservation of Lichtenstein Castle'', the walls were restored in [[1980 in Germany|1980]], continued with the second floor in [[1998 in Germany|1998]], and were completed with the upper floor and roof in [[2002 in Germany|2002]]. Still owned by the Dukes of Urach, the castle is open to the public via guided tour, although some rooms may not be entered. The courtyard is open to the general public, allowing the gun emplacements on the walls to be viewed. ==Schlossherren== [[File:Schloss Lichtenstein W.jpg|thumb|right|Aerial view]] [[File:LichtensteinHonau.jpg|thumb|right|The castle on its escarpment]] * 1837–1869: [[Wilhelm Graf von Württemberg]], from 1867 Duke of Urach * 1869–[[1928 in Germany|1928]]: [[Wilhelm Karl of Urach]] * [[1981 in Germany|1981]]–[[1991 in Germany|1991]]: Karl Anselm von Urach * [[1991 in Germany|1991]]: Wilhelm Albert von Urach ==In popular culture== *Schloss Lichtenstein has appeared postage stamps in the past. In the [[1940s in Germany|1940s]], during the [[French Zone of Occupation|French occupation of Germany]], authorities issued a series of stamps that included an 84-Reichspfennig stamp showing the castle, and the [[Deutsche Bundespost Berlin]] issued a 35-Pfennig stamp depicting the castle in [[1982 in Germany|1982]].{{cite web|title=Schloss Lichtenstein, german stamp 1982|url=http://www.german-stamps.org/frg-stamps-1982/schloss-lichtenstein-82|publisher=German-Stamps.org|date=16 June 1982}} *1826: In [[Wilhelm Hauff]]'s popular romantic novel, ''[[Lichtenstein (novel)|Lichtenstein]]'', the original medieval castle is the namesake and primary locale of the story. *2009: Lichtenstein was used for the filming of the German adaption of the original ''[[Grimms' Fairy Tales|Grimm's Fairy tale]]'', ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Dornröschen (2009)|de|3=Dornröschen (2009)|lt=Dornröschen}}'' ({{lang-en|[[Sleeping Beauty]]}}).{{cite web|title=Burg Hohenzollern & Schloss Lichtenstein|url=http://www.rbb-online.de/maerchenfilm/archiv/dornroeschen/burg_hohenzollern.html|publisher=Das Erste}} *Lichtenstein Castle is the inspiration for [[Super Street Fighter 2#Characters|Cammy]]'s home stage in the arcade game, ''[[Super Street Fighter II]]''.{{cite web|last1=Walden|first1=Matthew|title=15 Incredible Street Fighter Stages|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gallery/15-incredible-street-fighter-stages-you-can-visit-/2900-93/7/|publisher=Gamespot|accessdate=April 2, 2015}} ==Recreations== In 1862, a castle was constructed in [[Lietzow]], at [[Bergen auf Rügen (Amt)|Bergen auf Rügen]], [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]], that copied much from Lichtenstein castle. The "Leckzapfen" [[vineyard]] house constructed at [[Osthofen]] in [[1891 in Germany|1891]] in [[Worms, Germany|Worms]] in the [[Rhenish Hesse]] is almost a miniature version of the main hall of Lichtenstein Castle.{{cite web|title=Miniaturburg Leckzapfen|url=http://www.rheinhessen.de/sehenswuerdigkeiten-rheinhessen/a-miniaturburg-leckzapfen}} Reynier Fritz, a German-born [[Cape Town]] businessman well known in advertising circles, first saw the 19th-century ''Schloss Lichtenstein'' in the land of his ancestors and decided to one day replicate it in upon his return to [[Hout Bay]], South Africa. He was able to start building in 1986 and 12 years later it was completed,{{cite web|title=Hout Bay's famous castle sold for R23m|url=https://www.property24.com/articles/hout-bays-famous-castle-sold-for-r23m/16272|publisher=property24|accessdate=12 September 2012}} and he eventually turned it into a guest house before he died there.{{cite web|title=Spooky castle gets new owner|url=http://www.news24.com/Archives/City-Press/Spooky-castle-gets-new-owner-20150429|publisher=News 24}} Sometime after his death, his widow, Christine, sold it to an overseas buyer. Although allegedly haunted, the castle is considered one of the area's more popular attractions. In 2012, the castle was sold for 23 million [[South African rand|Rand]] to a Russian business man. While the business man himself remains yet unnamed, his wife's name is apparently Svetlana Besfamilnaya.
